previous.name: A Realized One Neither Exists Nor Doesn’t Exist

segments.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
segments.en: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

segments.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā, esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
segments.en: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
“Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

segments.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
segments.en: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

segments.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
segments.en: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

segments.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya—
segments.en: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

segments.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
segments.en: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:
‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

segments.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya
segments.en: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

segments.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati, dukkhaṃ upādāya, dukkhaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
segments.en: “And so, when suffering exists, because of grasping suffering and insisting on suffering, the view arises:

segments.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā, esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti.
segments.en: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, such a view is given up.
